awd_titl_txt: Bottom Stress and the Generation of Vertical Vorticity Over the Inner Shelf
awd_abstract_narration:
Small, kilometers-scale eddies play a critical role in the exchange of water between the shallows adjacent to the coast and the deeper ocean. These eddies are largely controlled by the friction at the sea floor, which itself depends on many parameters ranging from the roughness of the bottom topography to the density distribution in the water column. Recent evidence shows that simple, tunable formulations for bottom stress perform better in numerical models than more sophisticated ones based on physical mechanisms. Better understanding of the small-scale physics leading to bottom stress is needed for more accurate numerical models that do not need tuning with observations. This study will make detailed and extensive measurements near the sea floor to develop the needed understanding.

Current models describe the dependence of the bottom stress on the near-bottom current, near-bottom velocities produced by surface and internal waves, seabed composition, bedforms, and stratification caused by heat, salt and suspended sediment. However, recent regional-scale simulations suggest that use of these stress models degrades regional-scale simulations of currents relative to those based on simpler drag laws. Recent measurements and large-eddy simulations suggest that Langmuir Circulations might penetrate to the seafloor and disrupt the near-bottom flow and drag relationships, and recent stress measurements and particle-image velocimetry suggest that the longstanding models might over-predict the dependence of the bottom stress on surface gravity waves and over-simplify the near-bottom flow over large wave-formed sand ripples. This observational study will combine direct-covariance measurements of the bottom stress with corresponding measurements of the quantities that have been hypothesized to influence the bottom drag law. It capitalizes on a separately funded, concurrent, co-located study of exchange and dispersion across the inner shelf that will include measurements of surface currents by high-resolution high-frequency radar, water-column measurements of currents and stratification, measurements of wind forcing, and regional-scale simulations. Analysis of the resulting combined measurements and simulations will produce new insights into the dynamics of the bottom stress and its role in the vorticity dynamics that govern kilometer-scale eddies and transport across the inner shelf.

Intellectual Merit :
This study will produce a comprehensive data set with measurements of the bottom stress and all of the quantities that have been hypothesized to influence the bottom drag law. Analysis of the data set will produce new insights into the mechanics of the bottom stress, an evaluation of longstanding models and the role of processes such as Langmuir Circulations that have not yet been incorporated into bottom stress models, and ultimately an improvement of the physics of bottom stress models. The measurements and analysis of bottom stress will contribute an important new element to the separately funded concurrent regional-scale measurements and simulations of surface velocities, water-column currents and stratification, and wind forcing, which will lead to a new understanding of the generation and damping of vertical vorticity over the inner shelf.

Broader Impacts :
This research will lead to improved models of the bottom stress, which will improve predictions of eddies and other motions that control the movement of water masses and water-borne substances, including sediments, larvae and nutrients, from shallows adjacent to the coast to the larger mid- and outer shelf regions. Improved predictions will enhance the ability of coastal scientists, engineers and planners to address societally important applications including harmful algal blooms, transport and fate of pollutants, and search and rescue operations. The PIs have a history of mentoring at WHOI and USGS as well as interacting with coastal managers and planners. The study will support a recent doctoral graduate in the WHOI-USGS Postdoctoral Scholar Program and provide training and experience in a wide range of coastal oceanographic problems, methods, and applications.

por.por_cntn:
The drag or bottom stress imparted by the seafloor on ocean currents has a profound effect on a range of oceanographic processes, particularly in shallow coastal regions of significant human interest.  The bottom stress retards wind-driven and tidal flows, impacts bottom-dwelling organisms, is the agent for transportation of seafloor sediments, and generates kilometer-scale eddies that affect the transport and fate of waterborne substances, including marine organisms and pollutants.  The magnitude and direction of the bottom stress have been hypothesized to depend on a number of factors, including the strength and direction of the overlying oceanic current, the seafloor roughness, and the frequency and height of ocean surface waves, which are known to interact with oceanic currents in a centimeters-thick layer just above the seabed.  Theoretical models of these effects exist, but they are poorly tested in the ocean because of the absence of direct measurements of the bottom stress.  Incorporation of incompletely tested and verified models of the bottom stress has been shown to degrade, instead of improve, widely used computer simulations of currents in the coastal ocean. 

This study has addressed two important problems related to the bottom stress.  The first is the measurement of the bottom stress under natural conditions.  The second is the evaluation of existing models of the bottom stress against high-quality measurements of all of the factors that have been hypothesized to impact the bottom stress in the coastal ocean. 

The bottom stress is best measured by quantifying the chaotic velocity fluctuations, termed turbulence, that transmit momentum downward, resulting in seafloor drag.  Modern sensors are capable of the required measurements, but extraction and interpretation of the relatively weak but important turbulence in the presence of much stronger competing fluid motions, particularly those produced by ocean surface waves, is difficult.  This study isolated the turbulent motions by using two horizontally separated sensors, an approach that capitalizes on the disparity between the relatively small spatial scales of the turbulence and the much larger wavelengths of the surface waves.  These measurements were used to test a new mathematical model, developed through this project, of the cospectrum of the turbulent velocity fluctuations, which shows how the momentum transport is distributed among different scales.  Our measurements demonstrate that the turbulent cospectrum is distorted by surface waves in a manner that is predictable by using the mathematical model.  The new mathematical model of the cospectrum provides a means of interpreting, evaluating, and establishing confidence in the quality of the difficult measurements of the bottom stress.  

The second major goal of the study was the evaluation of existing models of the bottom stress against high-quality measurements, including the stress and all of the quantities that have been hypothesized to impact the stress.  These quantities include the magnitude and direction of the near-bottom ocean current, the frequency and amplitude of ocean surface waves, the seafloor roughness, and the vertical variation of the fluid density within the water column, which depends on the temperature and salinity.  Incorporation of all of these measurements, together with the new model for evaluation of turbulence measurements, provides the best existing quantitative test of models of seafloor drag in the coastal ocean.  The measurements indicate that over relatively fine seafloor sediments (finer than typical beach sands) where small three-dimensional ripples occur, the seafloor drag behave approximately as expected according to the existing theoretical models.  In contrast, over coarser sands, where large two-dimensional wave formed ripples occur, the bottom drag often departs from model predictions by orders of magnitude.  The completeness of the data set enables identification of the character and orientation of wave-formed sand ripples as the reason for the model-data discrepancy.  The ripples in coarse sand have much larger heights and wavelengths and their geometry is far more regular than the ripples found in fine sand.  When the current is perpendicular to the crests of these large ripples, the bottom stress is large and approximately consistent with existing models.  In contrast, when the current is parallel to the ripple crests, the bottom stress is much smaller, and nearly identical to the stress that would occur over a perfectly smooth seafloor.  This effect had previously been hypothesized, observed in the laboratory, and inferred indirectly from oceanographic measurements.  The new measurements provide quantitative oceanographic confirmation and result in a simple mathematical model that describes the magnitude of the effect.  The model is suitable for incorporation in widely used computer simulations and is expected to improve the fidelity of simulations with a number of real-world oceanographic processes.
